source.name: City of Calgary Waste & Recycling Services
source.notes: Based on official City of Calgary blue cart guidelines. Stretchy plastic bags accepted if bundled and tied (unusual!). Shredded paper in see-through bags. EPR reduced fee to $2.17/month.

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: No need to bundle or tie
notes: Inserts and flyers can stay with the newspaper
Blue cart recycling fee reduced to $2.17/month from April 2025 (EPR)
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines and flyers
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples

materials.name: Envelopes
instructions: Window envelopes are accepted — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Padded envelopes with plastic bubble lining should go in the garbage
commonMistakes: Don't include padded bubble-lined mailers — those are garbage

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: All clean paper accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in blue cart or beside it if too large
notes: Large cardboard can be placed beside the blue cart on collection day
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease — that goes in garbage
Remove all styrofoam and packing peanuts

materials.name: Boxboard / thin cardboard
notes: Thin cardboard boxes are accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic liners if possible
Don't include if heavily soiled with food

materials.name: Clean paper cups
instructions: Rinse and place in blue cart
Must be clean — no food residue
notes: Calgary accepts clean paper cups in the blue cart, unlike many cities
commonMistakes: Don't include cups with heavy food residue — those go in green cart
Don't include foam cups — those go in garbage

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a see-through plastic bag
Place bagged shredded paper in blue cart
notes: Calgary specifically requires shredded paper in a see-through plastic bag, tied closed — this is unique
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue cart
Must use a see-through bag, not opaque

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: Rigid plastic containers #1-7 accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Milk jugs
notes: HDPE #2 plastic — highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave milk residue inside

materials.name: Yogurt tubs and containers
notes: All rigid plastic dairy containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include lids smaller than 7.5cm — those go in garbage

materials.name: Plastic clamshell containers
notes: Clear plastic clamshells accepted in Calgary
commonMistakes: Don't include foam clamshells — those are garbage

materials.name: Plastic takeout containers
notes: Rigid plastic takeout containers #1-7 accepted
commonMistakes: No foam takeout containers — those are garbage
Rinse to remove food residue

materials.name: Laundry detergent bottles
notes: Large rigid plastic bottles accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles that contained hazardous chemicals other than common household cleaners

materials.name: Shampoo and personal care bottles
notes: Rigid plastic personal care containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include pump tops — remove and put in garbage

materials.name: Stretchy plastic bags (bundled)
instructions: Bundle all stretchy plastic bags together inside one bag
Place the bundle in the blue cart
notes: Calgary uniquely accepts stretchy plastic bags in curbside recycling if bundled and tied — most cities do NOT accept these curbside
Includes grocery bags, bread bags, produce bags, bubble wrap, and shipping bags
commonMistakes: Must be bundled in one bag and tied — don't put loose bags in the cart
Don't include non-stretchy rigid plastics in the bag bundle
Don't include chip bags or candy wrappers — those aren't stretchy

materials.name: Plastic lids (larger than 7.5cm)
instructions: Plastic lids larger than 7.5cm (3 inches) go in the blue cart
Lids smaller than 7.5cm go in the garbage
notes: The 7.5cm threshold ensures lids are large enough for sorting machinery to process
commonMistakes: Don't put lids smaller than 3 inches in the blue cart — they fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in garbage
Don't include ceramics, mirrors, or window glass

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include jar lids in the blue cart unless they are metal

materials.name: Food cans
notes: All metal food cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Tin foil / aluminum foil
instructions: Ball up into a fist-sized ball
notes: Must be clean — heavily soiled foil goes in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food
Don't include foil-lined bags (chip bags) — those are garbage

materials.name: Tin containers
notes: Metal containers accepted in Calgary blue cart
commonMistakes: Remove plastic or paper inserts first

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized — take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go

materials.name: Aluminum beverage cans
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
Beverage containers can also go to a bottle depot for refund
commonMistakes: Don't crush — keep 3-dimensional for sorting

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Replace cap if it has one
notes: Gable-top and aseptic (Tetra Pak) cartons both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten — keep 3-dimensional

materials.name: Pizza box (clean)
instructions: If the pizza box is clean or has minimal grease, place in blue cart
Tear off and recycle the clean lid; compost the greasy bottom
notes: Clean portions of pizza boxes are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily greased portions — those go in the green cart

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food scraps in the green cart
Includes meat, bones, dairy, cooked food, raw food
Use compostable bags or newspaper to line your kitchen pail
notes: Calgary's green cart accepts all food waste including meat and dairy
Green cart collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the garbage if you have green cart service
Don't use regular plastic bags in the green cart

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put fruit stickers in the green cart — peel them off

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetables accepted
commonMistakes: Remove twist ties and elastic bands first

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green cart — Calgary accepts ALL meat and bones
Includes raw and cooked meat, poultry, fish, bones
notes: Calgary's industrial composting handles meat and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the garbage — compost it

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place dairy products in green cart
notes: Rinse and recycle the container separately in the blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy in the garbage — compost it

materials.name: Bread and grains
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place coffee grounds, filters, and tea bags in green cart
notes: Paper coffee filters accepted in Calgary green cart
Compostable tea bags accepted; remove staples if present
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic-mesh tea bags in green cart — those are garbage

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush for faster breakdown

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Branches must be under 30cm (12 inches) long and under 7.5cm (3 inches) in diameter
Yard waste seasons may have extra collection
notes: Green cart accepts food waste and yard waste together
Large yard waste can go to City of Calgary landfills
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't include branches over the size limit

materials.name: Pizza box (greasy)
instructions: Greasy pizza boxes go in the green cart
Tear off clean portions for the blue cart
notes: Calgary green cart accepts food-soiled paper and cardboard
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the blue cart

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Food-soiled paper is accepted in Calgary composting
notes: Unlike Denver, Calgary does accept food-soiled paper in the green cart
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the blue cart — it contaminates recycling

materials.name: Compostable bags
instructions: Use certified compostable bags to line your kitchen pail
Place filled bag in green cart
notes: Look for BPI or CMA certification
Newspaper can also be used as a liner
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — only certified compostable
Don't use bags labeled 'biodegradable' — must be certified compostable

materials.name: Foam containers / styrofoam
instructions: Not accepted in Calgary blue cart or green cart
notes: Foam/styrofoam cannot be processed by Calgary's recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't put foam in the blue cart
Don't put in the green cart

materials.name: Non-stretchy plastic film
instructions: Not recyclable — these are not stretchy
notes: Only stretchy bags are accepted in the blue cart when bundled. Non-stretchy metallized bags are garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put chip bags or candy wrappers in the blue cart
Don't bundle with stretchy bags

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups (soiled)
instructions: Soiled disposable cups go in the garbage
Clean paper cups can go in the blue cart
Plastic lids go in the blue cart
notes: Clean cups are recyclable in Calgary; soiled ones are not
commonMistakes: Don't put soiled cups in the blue cart

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green cart
Don't put in the blue cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in black garbage cart
notes: Pet waste is not accepted in Calgary's green cart composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green cart

materials.name: Receipts
notes: Thermal receipts contain BPA
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue cart

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue cart with glass
Don't confuse with glass

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
notes: Different composition from container glass — not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue cart

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment
notes: Wax/silicone coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue cart
Don't put in the green cart

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
notes: Too small for recycling sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue cart

materials.name: Hangers and wrapping paper
instructions: Hangers: place in black garbage cart (or donate to dry cleaner)
Plain paper wrapping with no coating: blue cart
notes: Wire hangers tangle recycling machinery
Wrapping paper scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put hangers in the blue cart
Don't put metallic or glittery wrapping paper in the blue cart

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to a City of Calgary Throw 'n' Go drop-off depot
Or take to an Alberta Recycling-registered collector
notes: Calgary has multiple Throw 'n' Go depots that accept electronics
Electronics are banned from Calgary landfills
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in any curbside cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot or a participating retailer
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
Car batteries: return to auto parts store
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage trucks — never put in garbage
Call 311 for battery disposal questions
commonMistakes: Don't put batteries in any curbside cart
Tape terminals to prevent fire

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Or take to a paint retailer that accepts returns
notes: Alberta has a paint recycling program through product stewardship
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in the garbage

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Canadian Tire and auto parts stores accept used oil
notes: Alberta ARMA program manages used oil recycling
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Most pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications
notes: Alberta ENVIRx program — pharmacies accept medications for free
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Or take to participating retailers (Home Depot, IKEA)
notes: Product stewardship program covers fluorescent lighting in Alberta
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart
Don't break them — mercury vapour is hazardous

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Never put in any curbside cart
notes: Pressurized containers are explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in any cart

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Value Village, Goodwill, or Calgary Drop-In Centre
Textile recycling bins located throughout Calgary
Worn-out textiles still accepted at textile bins
notes: Calgary has multiple donation and textile recycling options
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in any curbside cart

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Or take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
notes: Alberta Recycling tire program provides free recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Or schedule large item pickup through 311
notes: Appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart
Remove refrigerant from cooling appliances first

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Or schedule large item pickup through 311
notes: Some mattress recycling programs available
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot
Small amounts can be absorbed with paper towels and put in garbage
notes: Never pour oil down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Take to a Calgary pharmacy or Throw 'n' Go depot
notes: Never place loose sharps in any cart
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in any cart

materials.name: Books
instructions: Damaged books: place in blue cart
notes: Donating is preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the garbage

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data
Take to a Calgary Throw 'n' Go depot or electronics retailer
notes: Phones contain valuable recoverable materials
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in garbage — battery fire risk

recycle: Paper: newspaper, magazines, flyers, envelopes, office paper
Shredded paper (in see-through plastic bag, tied closed)
Rigid plastic containers #1-7 (bottles, jugs, tubs, clamshells, takeout containers)
Stretchy plastic bags (bundled in one bag, tied closed — grocery, bread, produce, bubble wrap, shipping bags)
Metal food cans, tin foil (balled up), tin containers
compost: ALL food waste — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Yard waste — grass, leaves, small branches
trash: Non-stretchy plastic film (chip bags, candy wrappers)

tips: Calgary uses 3 carts: BLUE (recycling), GREEN (compost), BLACK (garbage)
Blue cart fee reduced to $2.17/month from April 2025 thanks to Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR)
Stretchy plastic bags are accepted in the blue cart — bundle them in one bag and tie closed (unique to Calgary!)
Shredded paper must go in a see-through plastic bag, tied closed
Plastic lids must be larger than 7.5cm (3 inches) to go in the blue cart
Food-soiled paper goes in the GREEN cart, not garbage
Calgary Throw 'n' Go depots accept electronics, batteries, paint, chemicals, and other hard-to-recycle items
Beverage containers can go to a bottle depot for a refund
Call 311 or visit calgary.ca/waste for disposal questions
Download the Calgary Waste & Recycling app for collection schedules

locations.name: Calgary Throw 'n' Go (Spyhill)
locations.notes: Free for Calgary residents. Bring proof of residency.

locations.name: Calgary Throw 'n' Go (Shepard)
locations.notes: Free for Calgary residents. East Calgary location.

locations.name: Bottle Depot (various locations)
locations.notes: Refund available on eligible beverage containers. Multiple locations across Calgary.
